headline.print_headline: Study Finds Sharp Rise Of Diabetes In Youths
headline.main: Diabetes on the Rise Among Teenagers

docs.abstract: A study found a sharp increase in the disease's prevalence among teens, adding to worries that diabetes may progress more rapidly in children than in adults.
docs.snippet: A study found a sharp increase in the disease's prevalence among teens, adding to worries that diabetes may progress more rapidly in children than in adults.

headline.print_headline: Sleep Apnea Is Linked to a Higher Risk for Cancer
headline.main: Sleep Apnea Tied to Increased Cancer Risk

docs.abstract: Two new studies associate a common disorder of sleep that causes pauses in breathing with a higher risk of cancer.
docs.snippet: Two new studies associate a common disorder of sleep that causes pauses in breathing with a higher risk of cancer.

headline.seo: High Bridge Restoration in New York City Will Start in Summer
headline.print_headline: Restoring an Old Bridge, and a Vital Link Between Neighbors
headline.main: Restoring a Bridge, and a Link Between Neighbors

docs.abstract: High Bridge, 1,200-foot-long pedestrian crossing between Highbridge section of the Bronx and Washington Heights in Upper Manhattan, has been closed for about 40 years; span will reopen to pedestrians and bicyclists after $62 million restoration project that is set to begin in coming months.
docs.lead_paragraph: The long-closed High Bridge, for which the Highbridge section of the Bronx is named, is to be restored, and some residents hope it will lead to a little more community pride.
docs.snippet: The long-closed High Bridge, for which the Highbridge section of the Bronx is named, is to be restored, and some residents hope it will lead to a little more community pride.

headline.seo: HDL ‘Good Cholesterol’ Found Not to Cut Heart Risk
headline.print_headline: Doubt Cast on the ‘Good’ in ‘Good Cholesterol’
headline.main: Doubt Cast on the ‘Good’ in ‘Good Cholesterol’

docs.abstract: New study published online in The Lancet finds that people who inherit genes that give them naturally higher levels of HDL, or 'good cholesterol,' throughout life have no less heart disease than those who inherit genes that give them slightly lower levels; researchers not associated with the study find the results compelling and disturbing.
docs.lead_paragraph: People genetically prone to higher levels of HDL, often called “good cholesterol,” showed that they did not have any significant decrease in risk of cardiovascular disease.
docs.snippet: People genetically prone to higher levels of HDL, often called “good cholesterol,” showed that they did not have any significant decrease in risk of cardiovascular disease.

headline.seo: Pepsi and Competitors Scramble as Soda Sales Drop
headline.main: Soda Makers Scramble to Fill Void as Sales Drop

docs.abstract: Americans are drinking fewer sugary carbonated beverages, forcing some of the best-known brands like Coke and Pepsi to rethink their strategies and rely more on 'flat' drinks and bottled waters; it is unclear if the trend will even out or if the decline is the beginning of a paradigm shift away from soda drinking in America.
docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are abandoning carbonated drinks, and Coke and Pepsi are relying more than ever on the “flat” drinks and bottled waters.
docs.snippet: Americans are abandoning carbonated drinks, and Coke and Pepsi are relying more than ever on the “flat” drinks and bottled waters.

headline.main: United States Ranks Last on Breast-Feeding Support

docs.abstract: A new Save the Children report ranks the United States last among 36 industrialized nations on its breast-feeding policies. Are you surprised?
docs.snippet: A new Save the Children report ranks the United States last among 36 industrialized nations on its breast-feeding policies. Are you surprised?

docs.abstract: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at what's happening in Washington.
docs.snippet: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at what's happening in Washington.

headline.seo: Gustavo Rivera, Bronx Lawmaker, Seeks a Sharp Contrast With His Predecessor
headline.print_headline: Bronx Lawmaker Seeks a Sharp Contrast With His Disgraced Predecessor
headline.main: Bronx Lawmaker Seeks a Sharp Contrast With Disgraced Predecessor

docs.abstract: New York State Sen Gustavo Rivera, who ousted disgraced Sen Pedro Espada Jr and follows a string of criminal senators from his section of the Bronx, seeks to make a name for himself as an honest politician; the Bronx, New York's poorest borough, is in need of unimpeachable leaders to reverse the ravages of crime, unemployment and health problems, but has been plagued by a culture of self-interest and corruption.
docs.lead_paragraph: With two of his predecessors having served jail time and a third facing it, Gustavo Rivera, a state senator representing the northwest Bronx, is trying to convince constituents of his integrity.
docs.snippet: With two of his predecessors having served jail time and a third facing it, Gustavo Rivera, a state senator representing the northwest Bronx, is trying to convince constituents of his integrity.

docs.abstract: Interview with mathematician and physicist Dr Carson C Chow, an investigator for the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases.
docs.lead_paragraph: Carson Chow has used mathematical models to determine the causes of obesity, and ways to stem the epidemic.
docs.snippet: Carson Chow has used mathematical models to determine the causes of obesity, and ways to stem the epidemic.

keywords.value: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE WEIGHT OF THE NATION More than two-thirds of the adults in the United States and one-third of children are overweight, leading to an increase in deaths from heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, stroke and kidney disease. This four-part documentary -- a collaboration by HBO, the Institute of Medicine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health -- is at the center of a public health campaign that includes a book, a social media component and an effort to reach more than 40,000 community groups. Part 3, ''Children in Crisis,'' looks at the struggle of overweight children and at their medical issues; above, a middle school gym class in Austin, Tex. It also examines school lunch standards and the debate over the definition of good nutrition among food and beverage makers, researchers and the government. The conclusion, ''Challenges,'' at 9:10, explores factors behind the obesity epidemic, including subsidized agriculture, evolutionary biology, racial and socioeconomic disparities, physical inactivity and the strong influence of the food and beverage industry. ''It wouldn't surprise me if people look back on the early part of the 21st century and call this the obesity era,'' says Dr. Thomas Farley, the New York City health commissioner. 9 A.M. (Sundance) ENCOUNTERS AT THE END OF THE WORLD (2008) For this documentary Werner Herzog traveled to Antarctica, where he met scientists and journeymen at the American outpost McMurdo Station and the penguins, seals, clams and jellyfish that surround them on what might as well be another planet. ''Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does, or as inexorable,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. One of the film's beauties, Ms. Dargis said, ''is that all the furry and floating animals are no more wondrous than the bipeds tramping through and around McMurdo: the linguist turned philosopher, the banker turned bus driver, and the female adventurer who, for drama and odd entertainment, likes to have herself zipped up in a carryall bag. (She's her own baggage.) Mr. Herzog opens his mind, heart and eyes to all these wayfarers who -- despite the persistent strain of melancholy that touches each and every person who appears on camera -- seem eerily at peace at the bottom of the world.'' The film received an Oscar nomination for best documentary feature.
